data.message: Microsoft used to have (may be the still do have) a version of windows (Windows Home Server) which offers a lot of the private cloud functionality and you have full control of everything from the software and hardware, so you can install hard drives that will work to back up your data from all the machines in your network, stream music and videos ... Etc most of these features have been ported over to Windows 8 ( look up Storage Spaces) and other free open source special Linux distorts can do that too

Yeah, I remember Windows Home Server. It's nice but it's not what this post is about. Personal Clouds, as I see them, is a way for each user to run their own version of web services on their own machine (VM) in the cloud.

It's like hosting your own email service, calendar, node of a social network, blog, wiki, storage, etc. Think of every online service you're using and find an alternative to it that you can get it as a software rather than a service. Then, you deploy it to your VM and run it.
No more privacy or data-ownership concerns. It's like having your own always-on always-connected PC.

It would be accessible from your cell phone, and your browser. It would be very simple to deploy and maintain. Software would be deployed via an "App Store". you don't have to deal with configurations, or IIS/Apache or database or anything.
Read my comment here for more information on where the idea comes from http://www.amreldib.com/2012/09/personal-clouds.html?showComment=1360784925804#c6547505215811842125

It is possible but it is expensive, both money and time wise, especially if you don't want the hosting company to touch your stuff, so everything needs to be done by you like backups and security fixes and such things

Yes, so the idea is to come with a "platform" (for lack of a better word) that lets users find, deploy, maintain and use these online services easily. The model is a mix between App Stores, Ubuntu Software Center, and Microsoft IIS Web Platform.
